chapter.title: Chapter 1: Measurement
chapter.description: Test your understanding of units, dimensional analysis, significant figures, and measurement principles.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental SI unit?
questions.solution: The SI system has seven base units. Newton, Joule, and Watt are derived units. Kilogram (mass) is a fundamental unit.

questions.question: The principle of homogeneity states that:
options: All physical quantities must have the same units
An equation must be dimensionally consistent
The universe is uniform and homogeneous
Derived units are homogeneous with fundamental units
questions.answer: An equation must be dimensionally consistent
questions.solution: The principle of homogeneity requires that all terms added or subtracted in a physical equation must have the same dimensions.

questions.question: The dimensional formula for torque is:
questions.solution: Torque = Force × perpendicular distance. Dimensions are [MLT⁻²] × [L] = [ML²T⁻²].

questions.question: A light-year is a unit of:
questions.solution: A light-year is the distance that light travels in one year. It is a unit of astronomical distance.

questions.question: Which quantity has dimensions [ML⁻¹T⁻²]?
questions.solution: Pressure = Force / Area. Dimensions are [MLT⁻²] / [L²] = [ML⁻¹T⁻²].

questions.question: The 2019 SI redefinition was based on:
questions.solution: The redefinition based units on fundamental physical constants (like Planck's constant) to make them more stable and universally reproducible.

questions.question: Dimensional analysis can be used for all EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Dimensional analysis cannot determine dimensionless constants (like 1/2 or 2π) as they have no dimensions.

questions.question: The dimensional formula for angular momentum (mass × velocity × radius) is:
questions.solution: Angular momentum = mvr. Dimensions are [M] × [LT⁻¹] × [L] = [ML²T⁻¹].

questions.question: Which statement about significant figures is correct?
options: They indicate the reliability of a measurement
They are always equal to the number of decimal places
They are only important in theoretical physics
questions.answer: They indicate the reliability of a measurement
questions.solution: Significant figures communicate the precision of a measurement, including all certain digits and one uncertain digit.

questions.question: The meter is currently defined as:
options: The length of a specific platinum-iridium bar
The distance light travels in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 of a second
questions.answer: The distance light travels in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 of a second
questions.solution: This definition links the meter to the speed of light, a fundamental constant, and the second.

questions.question: Which represents the largest number of significant figures?
questions.solution: 0.00456 has 3 sig figs. 4.560 has 4 sig figs (trailing zero after decimal is significant). 456 has 3 sig figs. 4.56 × 10² has 3 sig figs.

questions.question: The main advantage of the 2019 SI redefinition is:
questions.solution: Basing units on fundamental constants allows any lab with the right equipment to reproduce them, removing reliance on a single physical object.

questions.question: In uncertainty propagation, when adding two independent measurements A ± δA and B ± δB, the uncertainty in the sum is:
questions.solution: For addition or subtraction of independent quantities, their absolute uncertainties are added in quadrature (the square root of the sum of the squares).

questions.question: Which is a vector quantity?
questions.solution: Displacement has both magnitude and direction (e.g., 5 meters North), while speed, distance, and mass are scalars.

questions.question: The sum 12.345 + 1.2 + 0.07 should be reported as:
questions.solution: In addition/subtraction, the result is rounded to the last decimal place of the least precise number, which is 1.2 (one decimal place).

questions.question: Arguments of transcendental functions (e.g., sin, log) must be dimensionless because:
options: Their Taylor series expansions would be dimensionally inconsistent
They can only be calculated with calculators
questions.answer: Their Taylor series expansions would be dimensionally inconsistent
questions.solution: The series expansion (e.g., sin(x) = x - x³/3! +...) requires adding terms of different powers. This is only dimensionally consistent if x is dimensionless.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a fundamental SI unit?
questions.solution: The fundamental unit of electric current is the Ampere (A). The Coulomb (C) is a derived unit of charge (1 C = 1 A⋅s).

questions.question: Which unit is equivalent to kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³?
questions.solution: Watt is the unit of power. Power = Energy / Time = kg⋅m²⋅s⁻² / s = kg⋅m²⋅s⁻³.

questions.question: In the multiplication 15.67 × 0.8, how many significant figures should the result have?
questions.solution: The result is limited by the measurement with the fewest significant figures. 0.8 has only 1 significant figure.

questions.question: What are the dimensions of the universal gravitational constant G?
questions.solution: From F = Gm₁m₂/r², we get G = Fr²/(m₁m₂). Dimensions: [MLT⁻²][L²]/[M²] = [M⁻¹L³T⁻²].

questions.question: The product 3.14159 × 2.0 should be reported as:
questions.solution: The result of multiplication must be rounded to the number of significant figures in the least precise measurement. 2.0 has two significant figures.

questions.question: Which quantity has dimensions of energy?
questions.solution: Work (Energy) = Force × Distance. Its dimensions are [MLT⁻²] × [L] = [ML²T⁻²].

questions.question: Order of magnitude of the number of seconds in a year is:
questions.solution: 1 year ≈ 365 days × 24 hr/day × 3600 s/hr ≈ 3.15 × 10⁷ seconds. The order of magnitude is 10⁷.

questions.question: The prefix 'pico' stands for:
questions.solution: Pico (p) is the SI prefix for a factor of 10⁻¹².

questions.question: A measurement that is very close to the true value is said to be:
questions.solution: Accuracy refers to the closeness of a measured value to a standard or known value. Precision refers to the closeness of two or more measurements to each other.
